snippet: The decrease came amid mounting criticism from civil-rights advocates who have argued that the practice of stop and frisk unfairly targeted minorities.
abstract: New York Police Department says police officers stopped, questioned and frisked people 533,042 times in 2012, down 22 percent from about 685,000 in 2011; civil-rights advocates argue practice unfairly targets minorities, vast majority of whom were released without charges.
lead_paragraph: The decrease came amid mounting criticism from civil-rights advocates who have argued that the practice of stop and frisk unfairly targeted minorities.

headline.main: Number of Frisks Fell in ’12, Police Data Show
